awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using protein function prediction to promote hypothesis-driven thinking in undergraduate biochemistry education
awd_abstract_narration:
Recognizing the national need for significant improvement in undergraduate STEM education, collaborators from six institutions (Rochester Institute of Technology, St. Mary's University, Oral Roberts University, Hope College, Ursinus College, and California Polytechnic University) will explore a new approach to introduce students to authentic research in biochemistry laboratory courses.  The project will test the hypotheses that engaging in authentic research will improve students' abilities to master key aspects of experimentation (experimental design, data processing and interpretation, and communication of research outcomes) and visualization (use of representations to communicate various aspects of the research process).  The project is likely to be transferrable to other institutions, and is an example of a cost-effective way to introduce course-based research into the undergraduate curriculum.

Biochemistry laboratory courses will be redesigned to include modules in which students will integrate computational and wet lab techniques as they characterize proteins whose three dimensional structures are known but to which functions have not been previously ascribed.  Because the project is focused on discovery, it is reasonable to expect that some of the students will produce novel results that will contribute to the field of biochemistry.  Formative and summative evaluation will address assessment of student learning gains in terms of improved conceptual understanding and visualization of experiments using a validated instrument composed of open-ended and closed-ended questions.  Faculty members and teaching assistants will be surveyed and interviewed about their satisfaction with the project, its usability, and the extent to which they see the project as part of their own and their students' development.  The project team will create and disseminate modules (promol.org) that form the core of a new curriculum for undergraduate biochemistry laboratory courses.  The results of the work will be presented at professional meetings, such as the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, and submitted to scholarly journals.

por.por_cntn:
There is a worldwide move in science education towards promoting undergraduate students’ knowledge of how research is done so that they can better understand the studies behind scientific facts and, if desired, embark on a research career themselves.  At many institutions it is not possible for students to take part in undergraduate research in professors’ labs, but it is increasingly possible for them to participate in so-called Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences, or CUREs. CUREs are formal laboratory exercises that provide opportunities for students to experience authentic research and to develop research and problem-solving abilities. Our NSF-sponsored, multi-institutional collaborative project has focused over the past few years on the development, implementation and evaluation of the Biochemistry Authentic Scientific Inquiry Laboratory (BASIL) CURE. This is a one semester lab module focusing on using computational and wet-lab techniques to assign functions to proteins, on the Protein Data Bank (PDB), of known structure but unknown function. Our group at Purdue has been responsible for the educational evaluation of the BASIL CURE and the participant students. Although CUREs, have been the focus of numerous publications across a wide range of scientific disciplines, there has been a dearth of educational research evidence in support of whether students actually develop any discovery-type research abilities during such experiences. Instead, there has been a greater focus on technical or procedural-type knowledge or general CURE skills that are too comprehensive to effectively assess. Towards addressing this issue, we have published two important papers. In the first paper, we reported on the development of a rigorous, data-driven, 5-step Process for Identifying Course-based Undergraduate Research Abilities (PICURA) that instructors of our BASIL CURE anticipate students will develop during the course. We termed the identified anticipated learning outcomes (ALOs), CURAs, after Course-based Undergraduate Research Abilities. We also argue that PICURA could make an important impact on the identification of research abilities being developed by students participating in other CUREs. In our second paper, we reported on the use of PICURA for the development of a taxonomy of 43 CURAs for the BASIL CURE and illustrated how the taxonomy might be used to inform the design of assessment tasks aimed at confirming whether students have actually developed the target CURAs. In so doing we made the important distinction between ALOs which are simply what instructors expect students to learn and what we termed VLOs, or Verified Learning Outcomes, which correspond to what students actually learn as demonstrated in student responses to the assessments.
